job_title: Business Analyst in New York, NY
pros:
- Good work-life balance: at least in the teams (technology, back-office in wealth management) I was in, everyone around you pretty much follows the 9-5 work schedule. There's no pressure or work that will make you think that you should stay late to work.
- you do work with people with different background and races (e.g. Indian, Asian, American, European etc.). Again in technology, back-office.
cons:
- Limited opportunities to grow and evolve in your career: if you are one of the young individuals seeking challenges and opportunities for you to grow and clim up the ladders. This may not be the right place for you. It can be very chill sometimes, and you pretty much have to work for certain number of years to get promoted. E.g. at least 2 years to become VP from associates and you are very likely going to stuck at VP position forever if you stay in the same company. 
- Managers can be nasty: when I was exiting from the company, the manager (ED) I had was going to take away all my accrued vacations days and ask me to leave early. I had to escalate to MD (Managing Director, a level above). Luckily I was able to use up my vacation days before I leave the company. I also know some stories from my peer about how disrespectful their managers were to them in all aspects (discrimination etc.) In some cases, escalating a level up doesn't work. You would need to go to HR to report them.
- limited pay or raise: don't expect big raises throughout the years other than cost of living level of raise.

This is made evident by the high turnover and attrition within that department. Also, management stood by dismantling a talented team because the head refused to give in the pressure of churning results to appease the business and not be independent and objective to help the firm manage the risks. So if you play the cards right and stand on the wrong side the law, then it’s the place to work.

review_title: Terrible work life balance, toxis athmosphere, Labor law violations (Budapest office)
pros: I worked for MS for more than 4 and half year. Its not a place where you can work with cutting edge technologies, but the compensation was great and the team moral was good (before covid).
cons:
My team got a new manager and maybe the covid hit the company heavily. My last year at the firm was a nightmare. I was worked for the Budapest office, be very-very careful when you apply here, situation changed a lot in the last year.

A few highlight from my last year:
-Manager told on a big team status call: "Everybody shall be able to answer calls even in the middle of night, you have to stay home because of covid, you have nothing else to do just work. (nice work-live balance)" 
-Huge amount of overtimes, oncalls in the last year (without any compensation, no extra money, no early leave next day). Somebody in my team even called on new years eve and worked untill 10 PM. Daily 10 hours of work was normal on my last 6 months.
-Managers are constantly lying (I was asked to only speak about overtimes and oncalls when the candidate directly asking it during the interview and always say the minimal information, hired people end up in completely different team, different technology, I had a coworker who resigned on his second day because it was complete different than what they told her during the interview).

-I have asked help from HR about the legal status of uncompensated oncalls and overtimes. I got a follow up email after a month, they said they need more time to answer my question. I resigned a little bit latter, but I didn't get any answer for more than 2 and half month from local HR about a labor law question (that's just ridiculous).

The compensation is still above average, so you can give a try if you want, but ask directly about on calls and overtimes during the interview. Ask follow up questions, and be careful because you can end up in a different team with fully different technology stack then they promise during the interview.

review_title: Lack of technical innovation and deteriorating culture
pros:
* Co-workers were generally bright, eager to learn, and helpful
* Good social scene (friendly co-workers, social clubs, free beer on Fridays, etc.)
* Development teams had lots of autonomy
* Good pay and great RRSP matching
* Some development managers and product managers were great
* Great work-life balance
cons:
* No technical vision. Technical matters felt like they were directionless. Build times were ever increasing. Some teams lacked oversight/review and pushed code that would not fly on more established teams. No team lead, tech lead, or architect roles.

* Lack of technical innovation. Relentless focus on new features and minimum viable product meant that innovation often fell by the wayside. Many teams continued to use old front-end tech even for green field work, or engage in procedural rather than object-oriented programming. No technical roadmap or strategy to move away from outdated parts of the tech stack was communicated or mandated. Encountered strong push back against moving to a true services architecture.

* Monolithic and legacy code base. Never felt like I had the time or support to break smaller services off from the monolith. Felt trapped in a cycle of "learn new and esoteric part of the monolith" and "accrete new feature onto the monolith".

* Cliques and tone policing. It felt like outspoken and extroverted 'rockstar' developers were rewarded with promotions. Often felt forced to be a 'cheerleader' despite the various issues listed here. Saw from co-workers experiences that sharing actual outlook might result in withholding of promotions or raises.

* Was acquired by Morgan Stanley. We lost sudo access to our machines. "Outside Business Interest" rules required you seek approval for accounts, move securities to particular banks, and report your positions. The sabbatical was taken away despite the fact that many people had been promised it as part of their employment.

* Did not feel like senior management were team players. We were told that, post-acquisition, Morgan Stanley would let the company keep one of its two big annual events: the manager retreat or the Christmas party. Senior management elected to keep their retreat, while everyone else lost the Christmas party.

* Aesthetics felt favoured over functionality. Rolling whiteboards were removed from the office with no consultation of the people that used them daily. MacBooks were rolled out before they were ready and despite being a worse development experience (longer build times, etc.).

* Did not eat their own dog food. Despite making software around implementing equity plans, the company stopped offering regular equity grants to its employees post-acquisition.

* Retention issues. It felt like the best and brightest were constantly leaving. The people I wanted to work with the most always ended up leaving, and ultimately so did I.

Then, and this happens to somewhere between 90% to 97% of the new hires for Financial Advisor, you do not meet your quota and you are told to leave. Like Amway, your boss keeps your clients. So that is the business model, your boss, who likely has been there ten years or more, hasn't prospected in years. He relies on fresh blood to bring him new clients. Unfortunately, 95% of the new recruits never hit their goals and are asked to leave.

review_title: Supportive team mates, very low paying job when you review the job responsibilities
pros:
Teammates are supportive and willing to help you through the chaos of the job.
The department at least new immigrant friendly when hiring new intakes.
Managers can be supportive when they have not been stressed out themselves.
cons:
The job title says customer service to justify very low pay, but you do a whole lot more than typical call center duties. There is an insane financial services workload going on and definitely does not justify the 41,000 per annum pay.
There is no clear path if you are looking to change teams and/or apply to internal roles.
Managers do not expect you to take a bathroom break when the call queue is busy, and you can take a leak on your desk for all they care. Taking bathroom breaks when you are not on your set break period can lead to you not receiving a bonus at the end of the year (trust me). You are asked to take calls, document procedures, open investigation tickets. and at the same time answer colleagues questions in the teams chatroom. Your manager can withhold bonus from you if you do not fall head over heels to desperately answer your colleagues questions.
There is just too much micromanaging.
They expect you to take your personal time to catch up read up on new updates, company required trainings, etc.
There's just so much internal bureaucracy going on if looking to advance your career within.
They try to make you take the US FINRA S7 and S63 examination (Canadian equivalent is CSC. FINRA has no use here in Canada beyond this job) yet the difference in pay is next to nothing for the added stress. Expect to take more calls if you English speaking only during busy times (your bilingual teammates can be idle for over an hour, yet you, and not them, are still expected to respond to emails).
Other departments (especially some members in the CSM and RM teams) look down on you and do not consider you worthy of being treated like a human, it doesn't look like the managers can do much about this.
During company events to appreciate customer/client facing teams, nobody recognizes the department and all the work we put in, who cares about a call center right?
Even more archaic processes after the cross over to Morgan Stanley. These processes more stressful and leave you burned out at the end of your shift.
And the pay once again, is very low!
